I live here, I have lived twenty years in this house; the prisoner George Pearson lives a few doors from me; I was in Pearson's garden about 4 o'clock this evening; I went after my calf which had got into Pearson's garden. He knocked me down with-a great stick about four times, he hit me. The stick was about 10 feet long, it was a clothes prop. He knocked my head all to pieces, I was 10 feet from him. He did not say a word to me, nor I to him. I fell on the ground from the first blow. He hit me three times afterwards. After the first blow was struck, while I was on the ground he said I was not a going to take the calf out of his garden. I got up again and drove the calf off the premises. Another man, my lodger, Joseph Hammond, came to my assistance, I was covered with blood—when I went into the garden, Pearson came from the granary with the pole, in about an hour or more. We had some conversation about some straw; he wanted a barrow load of my straw for his pig. He wheeled it out of the barn in my wheelbarrow. We had no words about the straw, I sold it to him for 3d. I have never had any quarrel with him. After he had struck me he put the prop behind the granary. He did not come to my assistance, Joseph Hammond came to me. I called out for Joe to help me take the calf out of the garden. I was able to walk into the house afterwards; I sent for the doctor soon after I came in.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You brought me in 4 lbs. of butter, about two hours or more before you struck me; I did not see you after I got into the garden before you struck me. I did not say when you drove the calf out 'Don't disturb the b——you did not leave me and go indoors till after you had struck me; you had a little straw in my barrow for your pig in the sty."

RICHARD MAYNARD (Constable West Sussex Constabulary.); On 26th October, I went to the deceased's house, and afterwards, in consequence of what Dr. Buckle said to me, I went with him to the prisoner's house—another constable went to the back, I went to the front; after ringing two or three times, the prisoner looked out from the upstairs window—I told him that Dr. Buckle and myself wanted to speak to him—he came down, and we went into his living room—I told him I was going to take him into custody on the moat serious charge of assaulting Mr. Upsdell, at the same time I cautioned him that whatever he said I should give in evidence against him—he replied "The last time I saw Upsdell was in my garden"—I then asked him to go through his back door into his garden—we went out and made a search, but found nothing—I took the prisoner to Chichester, and afterwards, by the superintendent's orders, I took him back to Hunston, and there Upsdell's depositions were taken in his presence—next morning, about 5 am., I went into the prisoner's garden, it is divided into three cross-paths, and in the third bed I found a large pool of blood; it was about twelve paces from the back of the granary, and about 10 or yards from the back door of Pearson's house—I traced blood from the large pool along the garden path through the hedge into Upsdell's meadow, and almost close up to his back door—I made another search, and found this pole (produced) hanging up by the granary in Pearson's garden, exactly where Upsdell said he had taken it from—I continued my search, and found this chopper (produced), about twenty-two strides from the pool of blood; it was chucked down about two yards from a chopping block—there was something sticking to the back which induced me to carry it to the doctor; it was some flick, or something, which I considered came from the deceased's cap.

Cross-examined. This bill-hook has got no handle—I did not tell the prisoner of Upsdell's death; he knew it—when I took him into custody, I charged him with the assault—he remained in custody for the assault after Upsdell's death—he said it was a bad job—he did not say he was sorry for it—the superintendent is not here; the prisoner did not say that the deceased had assaulted him, not to me or to anyone else—I was present the whole of the time; when the superintendent told himthat Upsdell was dead, he said "It is a bad job; what will they do with me now?"—that was all he said—he did not say that Upsdell had attacked him.

Re-examined. He was in the cell at the police-station when the superinten
dent told him that Upsdell was dead; I was by the side of the superintendent at the time—I remained there on duty for hours; I was there all the time the superintendent was there and for hours afterwards, and I am quite sure that neither to me or the superintendent did he say that he had been assaulted.

ERNEST COOK BUCKLE . I am a duly qualified surgeon, practising at Chichester—I was called on to attend the deceased about 5 o'clock on Thursday afternoon, 25th October, for a wound in the head—he had lost blood—the third finger of his left hand was bruised; it appeared to be a recent bruise, such as you get in a jamb—on the left wrist there was another bruise and slight abrasions; and on the forehead and nose there were slight scratches—upon a post-mortem examination I found a clean incised wound, about 4 inches long, on the left parietal bone, going right through the scalp, both plates of the skull, into the brain itself—there were no signs of bruising about the wound—there was no other wound on the head—on throwing back the scalp so as to lay bare the skull, there was no sign of bruising—the cut in the skull was a clean cut, the edges were

sharply defined, and it terminated more abruptly at the anterior part, that is towards the forehead, than the posterior; I mean that it was more perpen
dicular, not so sloping, as if made with an instrument thicker at the bottom than the top—there was a slight depressed fracture at the anterior part as well; that is what is called a star fracture; it was about the size of a fourpenny piece; the inner plate of the skull was driven down between 1/8 and 1/4 of an inch; the greater part of 'the wound was 1/4 of an inch deep, but in the centre of the wound, in the brain, it went very nearly £ of an inch—the width of the fracture of the bone was about 1/8 of an inch—the width of the external wound on the scalp was retracted to 1/2 an inch or more—when you cut the tissues they alway come back directly from muscular contraction—there was no indication whatever of a blunt instru
ment on the scalp itself—it was a clean cut wound—in my opinion it was impossible that it could have been done by this pole—I compared the bill
hook with the wound, and in my opinion such an instrument would produce such a wound—the deceased's cap was shewn to me by Mrs. Upsdell—I find in it now a perforation corresponding with the wound on the head; there is a cut about 4 inches long on the left side of the cap, it goes through the outer part and after that also goes through a small layer of wadding and through the lining of the cap—the blow must have been a violent one, with a sharp cutting instrument, to go through the cap, the lining, and down to the substance of the brain—you often get the star fracture by the actual violence without anything actually touching it—it is a kind of a spreading out of the force—the primary cause of death was inflammation, produced by the wound; he died from the effects of the violence to which he had been subjected—from the character of the wound I should think he must have been stooping at the time the blow was struck, or he might possibly have been on the ground; I can't say—he was a taller man than the pri
soner—I should say the person who struck the blow was in front of him—the bruises I have spoken of might have been caused at the same time, by the back of the same weapon, I mean the graze on the wrist and the jamb on the finger.

Cross-examined. I made a microscopic examination of what was on the bill-hook, not of the bill-hook itself—I could find no recent marks of its having been knocked about—it is very blunt—I examined it on the Satur
day, the 28th, following the Thursday—I stated before the Magistrate "There were two hairs adhering to it which were human hairs, but they had evidently been there some time "—that had reference to the pole—there were either rabbit or hare hairs, on the bill-hook, they corresponded with either—I was before the Magistrate and also before the coroner—the deceased never complained of being struck with a sharp instrument—I have been qualified as a medical man two years—there was a scalp wound.

Q. Is this correct: "It not unfrequently happens that bruised wounds of the scalp present the appearance of a clean cut, and look exactly as if they had been produced by some sharp instrument?"—A. They might do so, but I have never seen one; all the cut wounds I have seen in the hospital have been bruised as well; I have never seen a single one without—I do not know Mr. Prescott Hewitt personally—I would not undertake to differ with him if he says "Star wounds are for the most part accompanied by bruising of the soft part, but it not unfrequently happens that they present the appearance of a clean cut, as if produced by a sharp instrument"—the parietal bone is about the same consistency as most bones; it is not a very
thick bone—this cut penetrated through the inner and outer table of the skull.

MR. WILLOUGHBY, in reply to the Court, stated that he could not resist a verdict of Manslaughter, the act of the prisoner being an unlawful one; the only question being with what instrument the 'wound was inflicted.

GUILTY —
Fifteen Months' Imprisonment

105.
SARAH TULETT (24)
, Feloniously causing grievous bodily harm to her new-born child with intent to murder it.
MR. RAVEN conducted the Prosecution; and MR. BOXALL defended the Prisoner.

WILLIAM PABKER (Brighton Police). On Sunday morning, the 9th July, I was on duty in the London Road, Preston, about 7.30 a.m., and saw the prisoner walking in the direction of Brighton, from Preston—she had a bundle on her left arm—I wished her good morning, and she said "I wish you good morning, sir; what time does the train leave for Burgess Hill, as I have left my situation, and am going there for a few days; I have another one to go into, and am going to see some friends "—I was then close to her—I told her that I could not tell her what time the train started—I heard a noise inside her bundle, and asked her what the bundle contained—she said "Dirty clothes "—I told her that I must look inside the bundle, and see what there was, as there was something besides dirty clothes—she said nothing until I began to open the top part of the bundle, when she said "Oh! do let me go and bury it, for it is quite dead "—I saw the head of a child, and told her that it was not dead, for I could distinctly hear it making a noise, and that I must take her to the station, and I did so—the parcel was opened there, and it contained a female child, with the string of a petticoat tied three times round its neck, and the ends tucked underneath the folds—I sent for a cab, and took the prisoner to the work-house infirmary—the string was very tight.

COURT. Q. It could not have been on very tight or the child would have died, would it not, before you got to the station? A. It was wound round three times; it was not so very tight—the child's breathing resembled that of a puppy; it laboured very much when it was drawing its breath, I could see that—it appeared to be a great relief to the child when the string was taken off, it breathed much easier, and then began to cry—I asked the prisoner on the way to the station, where the child was born, she said in a field near the church at Preston, at 4 o'clock in the morning.

Cross-examined. What first attracted, my notice to the prisoner was that I saw her looking very ill, and a man told me she had been sitting by the church gate for three quarters of an hour—she is very deaf; she did not seem excited when she spoke to me—the noise inside the parcel attracted my attention—it was a parcel done up in brown paper, carried underneath her waterproof—the noise I heard was a cry resembling that of a puppy just born, or more of a moaning—I could not have heard it if I had been so far off as that door—I was touching her—she did not appear to hear the noise at all—I was about a mile from the police-station when I took her into custody, and she walked that distance with me—she carried the parcel, but I assisted her—I took hold of her arm, and assisted her along; she was in a very weak condition—she was not fainting then, but she did after I got to the station, and I got a cab—it took me about twenty-five minntes to get her to the station, and during that time I had not opened the bundle except

merely at the top, so that for twenty-five minutes the string which was, as I say, tight round the neck, had not been removed, and yet the child was breathing—I had only opened the parcel just enough to see the child's head—I did not see its face then because I saw she was in a very weak state, and I wanted to get her to the station—I did not think at the time that the child was in state to require immediate assistance—I could not judge whether the cry was that of a child undergoing the process of strangulation; at any rate, I did not open it till I got to the station—I was there when it was opened; the parcel was about 2 feet long, with several dirty petticoats, and the child inside them, and it was done up in brown paper—a petticoat was round the child—the string was still attached to the petticoat and the petticoat was wrapped round the child, and the brown paper round the petticoat—the petticoat was retained in its place by means of the tape round the neck—the end of the string, which was attached to the petticoat was the first round the child; I mean that the part of the string which was fastened to the petticoat; the part nearest to the petticoat went round the neck first—I went to the workhouse with the prisoner in a cab, and took the child with me—no medical man saw the child till some time after we got to the workhouse—two minutes after we got to the station I assisted in taking the string off the child's neck—we simply unwound it, we did not cut it, we simply took hold of the end and pulled it out—it came out. easily.

Re-examined. I took the prisener into custody when I saw the head of the child—the noise of the child first attracted my attention; it sounded like a child that had something round its neck—I cannot say whether the noise was like that of a child being suffocated—it was a free sound.

ELIZA COOK . I am a widow, and live at 1, Robert Street, Brighton—on 8th July, the prisoner hired my room for two nights, and came into it about 10 o'clock that evening—I heard her about very early in the morning,. which caused me to get up, and I saw her go out about 6 o'clock and cross the road, and turn up North Road; that is in the direction of Preston—she turned the corner, and I did not see her again till I saw her at the Town Hall—at 9 o'clock, a policeman came and told me something, in con
sequence of which I went into the room and examined the bed, and was fully convinced that a birth had taken place there, as I saw what is usual on such occasions—I am able to say that from my own knowledge.
Cross-examined. There was no appearance of concealment in the room more than decency required—I did not notice that the prisoner brought anything with her when she came.

DAVID RICHARDS . I am a surgeon to the work house infirmany, Brighton—on the morning of 9th July, the prisoner was admitted to the lying in ward, at about 8.30—I examined her and found that she had been recently delivered, but it was not complete; the child had been born, but the after birth had not been taken away—she said nothing at that time—I examined the child and found that the string had been cut, about a foot from the body and there was a mark round the neck, evidently produced by some string or tape; it was a narrow mark—the tape is not here; it was cut off—the neck was reddened as if from the pressure of a piece of string or tape; the skin was broken, and it took about a fortnight to heal—as far as I could judge that wound was caused by the pressure of a string.

By THE COURT. It was an abrasion of the skin and it ulcerated after
wards—the mark was just over the trachea—that is a spot where if there is

any tight pressure, even on a grown person, it would be serious, a grown person would be rendered absolutely powerless in a moment by any strong pressure there—the mark might have been accidental—a ligature round the neck must have been tight to produce that mark—supposing that the string was so tight as to cause the abrasion, it would be impossible for a newly born child to bear it.

By MR. RAVEN. In my opinion the string might have been tighter and become slackened—I believe that was accidental—the prisoner afterwards told me in the course of the day that she did not know what possessed her to try and kill the child—the child stayed in the infirmary, and the prisoner left well, on August 8th. (The child was now in the prisoner's arms.)

Cross-examined. She was in bed when I first saw her—I had to use ordinary force to complete the labour; it was not the process of nature—I merely asked her how it was she got into this trouble, and she told me she did not know what possessed her to try and kill the child—I think she heard my question—when I said "this trouble," I meant being arrested—she was in a very weak state, but she was able to speak; she had rallied then; she was walking about the ward in nine days or a fortnight, and the child took about a fortnight to recover; it was with its mother all the time, and I treated it for a laceration of the neck—the wound was about 1/8 of an inch long all round the neck—it was an abrasion—in newly-born children very little is required to make a serious wound—there is not a tendency in the, folds of the neck to show very bad signs, but there is lower down—I do not think the same cause that would bring forward a tendency to produce those marks would cause laceration—there was a mark on the windpipe—no lasting mark is left on the child—I was in Court and heard the whole of the case before the committing Magistrate—the prisoner is very deaf and there was no" one defending her—I did not hear the answers she made to the Magistrate's questions.

WILLIAM PARKER (re-examined). I was present before the Magistrate and heard the statement the prisoner made—she said "If the—string got there it got there by accident," The deposition being refered to only stated that ike prisoner said "I have nothing to say.").
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 11TH, 1876.
